description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:58001
Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=58001

This luggage tag is designed to fit a standard business card, but maybe your business is non-standard!  So of course you can customize it to fit whatever type of card you want.  It's a 2 piece print that bolts together at the corners and the pressure clamps the card in.  And just for fun it has an open-source hardware logo cutout in the back.

The default values provided will fit a standard business card and M3x10 screws.  Most configurable parameters are enabled for the customizer, or download the SCAD and mess with it as much as you want.  The (short) OSHW logo file is pasted directly in so that it's totally standalone.  There is a surprising amount of variation in business cards though, so be sure to measure yours and customize!  (Recommended ~.1mm extra in case of printer slop, dependent on your printer...)
The base has a 1 layer_height layer to act as a bridge to hold up the narrowing of the hex head to the bolt shaft diameter.  I would have just printed it the other side down, except a small indent for the card is a good idea.
If you want to waterproof it, just put some plastic wrap under and over, then bolt it down so you get a nice plastic-on-plastic "smush" seal, or, if a more robust solution is desired, laminate your card before insertion.  If lamination makes it too thick or too big or both, well, that's why it's customizable.  You probably only have to reprint the base if that's the case.  Also you can just print the solid base and tape a business card on with packing tape or the like, see the second one I made that is nice and thin to be used that way.
The height is specifically pretty thick for two reasons: (1) so it doesn't break, and (2) so the screws don't protrude at all.  But feel free to make it so that it does protrude, I didn't explicitly force the bolt length to be 'correct' in any way.
Basically, either print the plate() as-is, or call top() and bottom() to print that instead.
My printed copy is without logo because I added that while it was printing, but it should not affect anything, except for taking less plastic to print.

High School Junior Katie F. designed a K-9 last year in Sketchup, but the stl never worked.  This year she decided to do it in Inventor and it came out perfectly!   This was printed on our Stratasys/Dimension Uprint Plus because of the need for support material.

title: Tank Track, Double Idler, Arms, Beams

description.text:
These are what I ended up with for Idler Arms for the tank project. Double idlers and buggy shocks. Used buggy shocks with ball end and drilled hole for 6-32 bolt to go through arm.
These use the Tank Track, Idlers, spacers to complete the set in my things.
Tank Dbl Arm ML-R are for the middle, Tank Dbl Arm SL-R are shorter for the rear. Tank Dbl Arm Beam is the beam to hold Idler wheels for these arms. L and R are for left and right sides. Tank Dbl Arm FL-R are for the front and go with Tank Dbl Arm Beam FL-R. These have an extra spring on the beam to keep tension on the track as it comes off the track Idler wheel.
All of these Idler Arms take the same 1/4"x1/2" Shoulder bolts as single arms at frame pivot point.
When I made these I just happened to have some Kirby Vacuum cleaner #174091 Cord Hook Swivel bolts laying around that work great for the beam pivots. Threaded them all the way down and cut bolt off to fit. Since these may be expensive to buy, included a Tank Dbl Arm Pin that will take their place. Not sure how they will hold up compared to metal. Use 4x1/4" sheet metal screw and flat washer in pin to hold in place. Drill pin with .093" (#42) drill bit for screw hole.
There is a YouTube videos of the Tank with Traxxas dual Velineon brushless motors and dual 3S Lipo batteries.
Updated drill guide PDF added. This is a work in progress please check for updates.
Most of these need raft and support. Lots of filing and drilling to make them fit and move freely.

comments.text:
The overall height of the tank depends on how much suspension travel you want. My tank has about 2 1/2" of ground clearance a 1 1/2" frame and the tracks stick up above the frame about a 1/2". so the height of tank is about 4 1/2" tall. The tank has 1" of suspension travel. This give the tank a very smooth ride and it will climb hills very nicely.
Worm gear drives are noisy, but easy to use in this situation. The space saving design works well with the tank and drive takes up little space. A gear reduction motor or regular gear reduction like the Heng Long tanks use would be easy to make and gears are available online to do this. That design would be quieter but take up more room.
That is cool, because I am using this platform for a robotic tank also. I have installed a Arduino Micro board in the tank to control it. I am working of writing the software for it now.

description.text:
This is my Android-powered, automated cat feeder. A Python script runs via SL4A on the phone serving up a webcam feed and taking care of triggering the feeder on schedule. For more details, video, and code, see my blog entry here:
http://www.damonkohler.com/2010/11/android-automated-cat-feeder.html

To print this on a MakerBot, you'll need to be careful how you orient the STLs on the platform. They're a tight fit! You'll need to print two of the back brackets and one of the front. The motor is bolted on to the front bracket from the inside. So, you'll need to attach the drive shaft and motor to the bracket first and then use the brackets to mount the cereal dispenser.
When printing the drive shaft, I recommend using a raft. In addition, I got the best results when using comb and multiply to print a 2x2 matrix. This allows the layers to cool sufficiently, making a tall and skinny print possible.
If you intend to use the food chute, pay attention to the height you mount the cereal dispenser. The food chute is approximately 10cm high.

Magnetic slingshot Naval / BAE Magnetic Rail Gun at home:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wa_vuX5_oAk
Challenge your friends to epic battles, simple and fun. All you need are 12 magnets (10mm x 10mm x 10mm),
10 for the gun and 2 for the each bullet. My own working videos of the toy:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XDDJKN8NTS4
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iNpX8H8I23o Based on the video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VTbFfEEE_qU
In the video were used bigger magnets (20mm x 20mm x 10mm),
I used smaller and cheaper but also work well.
Thanks, antostoof1 You can help me to do more things like this.
Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

All you need:
You need 12 magnets (10mm x 10mm x 10mm).
10 for the gun.
2 for the each bullet. Attention:
Use neodymium magnets.
I believe it will not work with common magnets, they are not strong enough.
Use the blueprint image to align the magnets.
Align all magnets to same direction, do the same for the bullet.
I got better results with 2 magnets in the bullet, but also worked with 3 and 4.
Use tape to hold everything together.
I believe it should work for any arrangement 45 degrees and with ratio of 1 to 2 between the poles of the rail and the bullets.
Bullet field length 5mm x 4(N-S-N-S) and Rail field length 10mm x 5(N-N-N-N-N).
I found inverted fields configuration for bullets and rail working well too.
Always remembering to centralize the magnetic field in all directions.

comments.text: This one doesn't work because if you take a close inspection, the working models on youtube.com and elsewhere have the "N" (blue) and "S" (red) overlapping each other in line effectively forcing in this case a projectile of "NSNS" magnets through a completely "N" field.  For the above Rail Gun to work, the magnets will need to be arranged so that the lower "N" field completely lines up with the next magnets "S" field.

description.text:
Wish you had a Customizable, snakey, spiral-ly magic wand? Here's your chance!  
Aside from that, this is an experiment in using OpenSCAD's linear_extrude function, twisting and extruding a circle to form a cool magic rod. I then use the same technique to make screws and screw holes, allowing me to assemble a long magic wand from even a small build area. This technique of making screws and nuts is pretty simple to code and works well. Note that the screws and holes are pointed, so that the holes can print with 45 degree slopes inside (i.e. so no bridging). The wand requires no support to print (unless the wiggles are extreme) and minimal infil - none if you use several layers to make the tops solid.  
The way the sphere fits onto the head of the wand also looks pretty nifty, if I say so myself.  
Now Customizable!  
And fixed. Thanks to alfonso82  for pointing out a problem - one of the threads was generated screwing in counter-clockwise, and the rest were all clockwise. Oops! Thanks!  
And tweaked so cross-section view is rendered for the 'stacks' but full parts are rendered for plates and individual parts.

Print a top segment, a bottom segment, and as many 'middle' segments as you like. Screw just a top and bottom together and make a magic wand. Screw in a bunch of middle segments and you have a printed walking stick. I printed one in glow-in-the-dark for a Maker Faire, and had a blast. Play around with the parameters to generate wands of different sizes. In particular: shape = which part to print:

  • Top has a ball, and socket at bottom

  • Middle has screw at top, socket at bottom. Use lots of these to make a walking stick

  • Bottom has screw on top, tapered at the bottom

  • Plate with a Top and Bottom piece

  • Plate with four Middle pieces

  • Preview a 'short stack' showing how the top and bottom screw together. Don't print this.

  • Preview a 'long stack' showing how a Top, two Middles, and Bottom look assembled.
    • h = height of a rod segment (should be your print height) cr = radius of the circle that forms the rod w = distance of 'wiggle' in the rod, 2 is subtle, 10 is wacky (and might generate angles over 45 degrees depending on the number of wiggles) nw = number of 'wiggles' in each rod segment gap = the distance between each screw and the hole in the next rod segment. If they're too hard to screw together, make the gap larger so that there's more 'play'. Doesn't need to be too tight, as the rod segments tighten when screwed down. spacing = the spacing between rod segments arranged in a row and 'plated'. If you make the rod very wide, you will need to increase the spacing as well. c = 'crossiness'. 0 = spiral, 1 = spiral and counter-spiral, 2 = four spirals, forms cross pattern. You can also preview a 'short stick' of top and bottom or a 'long stick' of more. These are all of the segments lined up so that you can see what the combination will look like, for a preview.

description.text:
I laser cut the Gettysburg Address into a 8" x 12" Marble tile from Home Depot. I need a stand to display it. I took the simple IPad stand and imported the dxf into Visio. I then converted it to Visio objects and then shrunk the file down until the slot was 1/4 inch, the thickness of the acrylic. That happened to make it fit just inside the piece of acrylic. The slots also magically fit the width of the tile (.34").
I then added the image of Abraham Lincoln, even though he is hidden when the tile is in place.
Note Visio gave me issues when trying to cut it on a Universal (the printer so no lines to vector, just raster), so I switched the Epilog (yeah the Garage is awesome) and it worked fine, except the little bit that was out of print range, apparently. I did a quick .1 " cut to knock the piece out.
More details at my blog

If you need to change the sizes, open a editable version, or just used the PDF.
Most likely you will need to check the thickness of the material you are cutting, since it becomes the size of the slot needed. I made this slight less than .25 (like .24) since the material as measure was less than .25.

description.text:
UPDATE: After several test prints I think that this version of the gondola is not as good as previous v3. Somehow the movable mounts lead to less accurate, very curvy angles in the drawings. This is an enhanced (but slightly more complicated) version of a gondola (penholder) for a simple vertical plotter (like Polargraph, Makelangelo, Drawbot).
This design has movable mountings for the bead chains which create smoother moves and straighter lines compared to v3. You will need some additional M3 bolts and nuts to connect these mountings to the base plattform (see pictures).
The previos v3 does not need any assembly and fewer bolts and nuts. Find v3 here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:472573 See also the bead chain gear in my objects.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:467647 These models (and some electronic stuff) are all you need to build your own vertical plotter. Sandy Nobles (creator of Polargraph) great Instructables is a good point to start:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Polargraph-Drawing-Machine/?ALLSTEPS This is iteration 4 of the gondola. Far from perfect, still a work in progress.
Features:
  • Movable mounting arms for bead chains
  • Bead chains can be fixed with M3 screws
  • Pen can be fixed with M4 screw
  • Enough place to glue servo for pen lift
  • M3 hole for counterweight at the bottom(M5 would be better, could use M5 nuts then as weight)
    • You can see some more pictures here (text in german, sorry):
    http://www.makerblog.at/2014/09/vertikalplotter-im-selbstbau-teil-1-polargraph-kritzler-makelangelo-und-co/

When designing and building a scale, the mechanical design and the 3D-printing are just one aspect of the problem. In order for the scale to be of practical use, it's at least as important to also provide an easy method for generating a weight dial which is calibrated to that particular scale. This project tries to satisfy both of those needs. As for the constructional part, the provided files generate a mechanical letter scale using an old-fashioned classic design with a moving quadrant that contains the weight dial and a counterweight. The SCAD file is fully parametrized and commented, so that the size and strength of the scale can be adapted, if needed. By default, the scale is dimensioned to about the maximum size which still allows printing of the complete scale in on a single 20x20cm printing plate (actually it needs only 19x18cm). An STL file is provided for printing the complete scale on one single plate, as well as separate STL files for the individual parts. The maximum measurable weight the letter scale depends on the counter weight. I use as counterweight two M10 nuts, two M10 washers and a little piece of M10 rod, which results in maximum measurable weight of about 130g. Of course, the bigger the counterweight, the bigger will also be the maximum measurable weight. In addition, the levers contain a second set of weight pivot holes, that are 20% shorter and using these will increase the maximum weight accordingly. As each printed letter scale will be slightly different (type of filament, filling, screws, counterweight ...), it is not possible to use the same dial markings for all scales. Thus, it is very important to have a good and simple way to calibrate the scale. For this reason, a PostScript file is provided with this project, which helps calibrating the scale and also prints the properly calibrated scale dial. For the calibration, it suffices to measure two angles:

  • b0: the angle one between the lower leg of the scale quad rant and the vertical without weight on the scale

  • a1: the deflection angle for some known weight m1
    • To facilitate measuring these angles, the PostScript file contains a auxiliary dial with a graduation showing 0-90 degrees. Once the angles b0 and a1 have been measured, the values of b0, m1 and a1 (resp. a1+b0) in the PostScript file are modified accordingly and the file is reprinted, now producing a scale dial which is a properly calibrated for this particular letter scale. The two scales I have built and calibrated so far using this method are both precise to about the nearest gram. When mounting the scale, it is very important that the pivot axes have the least possible friction, so that the scale moves as freely as possible. I use small nails cut to the proper lengths as axes and drill the pivot holes to just the right size for the nail to turn freely. In order to keep the nails in place, I stick cut-off ends of cable binders onto the rear ends of the nails. If you plan to build this letter scale, I recommend you follow the procedure explained in detail on the instruction page...

To build this letter scale with a properly calibrated dial, I recommend the following procedure:

  • Print all the parts either from the complete single plate or by printing the parts individually.

  • Drill out the inner pivot holes (stand and weight stem) with a drill bit that is exactly the diameter of your axes (I use 1.4mm nails and 1.4mm drill bit), so that you have to use a bit of force to insert the axes. Drill the outer holes (quadrant and levers) a bit larger than the diameter of the axes (I use 1.8mm for the 1.4mm nails), so that the axes turn freely and without friction. Optionally use a M3 tap to cut a thread for the level adjustment screw into the vertical hole in the stand.

  • Print out the provided PostScript dial.ps file as it is. Make sure that the page is not scaled in any way, e.g. by measuring the 40mm box in the upper left corner. Cut out the auxiliary dial with the 0-90 degree marking and glue it to the scale, so that the 0 and 90 degree markings correspond to the notches in the dial quadrant. Don't use too much glue, as you need to remove it later and replace it with the calibrated weight dial! (If you have a PostScript printer, you can send the file directly to the printer, otherwise you might need some to install some of the freely available PostScript viewers, such as gsview.)

  • Mount a counterweight onto the 10mm hole on the end of the dial quadrant. The exact weight and size is not critical, as long as the counterweight does not touch the stand when the scale tray is empty(!). I use a short piece of M10 threaded rod with two M10 nuts and washers as counterweight.

  • Assemble the scale, making sure that the pendulum moves freely and with the minimum possible friction. Cut the nails for the axes so that they stick out about 4-5mm at the read and secure them with the ends of small cable binders. Bend a nail at right angle and put it into the hole in the stand underneath the dial, to serve as dial pointer.

  • Now that the mechanical part of the construction is finished it is important to make sure that it moves freely and with the least amount of friction. As a test, put a weight which moves the dial about half way and count the swings as you let it go. 5 swings is a good starting point, but with some tweaks and fine adjustments you should easily get to 7-8 swings, which is perfect. Be aware that after this step, no more changes should be made to any of the moving parts, as this would influence the center of gravity of the pendulum and, hence, introduce errors in the calibrated dial.

  • Put the scale (incl. weight tray) onto a horizontal surface and measure the angle b0 without any weight on the tray.

  • Put a weight with a known mass m1 onto the scale tray and measure the angle a1+b0.

  • Enter the values b0, m1 and a1+b0 on the corresponding lines of the provided PostScript file dial.ps. If necessary, also change the maximum weight and the foreground and background colors and reprint the PostScript file.
    ` 
    ...  
% Calibration without any weight:  
/b0 {2.4} bind def      % angle between vertical and lower leg of scale quandrant  
% Calibration with test weight:  
/m1 {100} bind def     % test weight m1 in grams  
/a1 {67.4 b0 sub} bind def% deflection angle angle for    test weight m1, if measured from notch  
% Scale definition  
/mmax {140} bind def     % maximum weight in grams  
/fgcolor {0 0 0 setrgbcolor} bind def % foreground color (  , all between 0 and 1)  
/bgcolor {1 0.97 0 setrgbcolor} bind def % background color (  , all between 0 and 1)  
...
    `

  • Cut out the (now calibrated) weight dial and glue it onto the dial quadrant. Note the 0 and 90 lines at the ends of the dial and adjust the to fit the notches on the dial quadrant.

  • Test the calibrated letter scale with the weight you used to calibrate it, it should now give the correct reading m1. If you have other know weights, it's now a good time to test the scale with these as well...
    • _For those who are interested in the formula and in the theory behind the calibration of the letter scale, I have prepared a little PDF document explaining it all..._

comments.text: Really interesting. What is the smallest weight that this can measure? Thanks.
comments.author: diy_engr_2014

comments.text: Well, that depends on the counter weight you use, the smaller it is, the quicker the scale will react on small weights.  Also, the dial uses 1g divisions, for smaller divisions you would need to adapt the PostScript file. Finally, the precision of the scale depends a lot on reducing the friction of the nails/needles which are used as pivots.  For the last few letter scales I built I constantly got the calibrated precision to be within 1 gram.

This one is based on the triceratops puzzles that exists in countless, near identical versions on the web and in toy shops. I have no idea who originally made this puzzle. I needed a small yet rugged triceratops for kids to dig out during a dinosaur themed week at our Science centre. I used pictures from the web and a few different kits I had lying around as guides, but made several adjustments, not only to scale. Due to the thickness of the sheets I use, I had to carefully reconstruct the parts to make the kit go together. The drawing I made prints as a framed kit, and you can fit 12 onto one 18'' X 24'' sheet of 1/8'' MDF, plywood or acrylic for aspiring palaeontologists to enjoy.

I drew the whole things with splines in Drawsight, from the kits I used as guides.The two "hip" parts are slightly different, one goes in the back, one in the front. Use them where you think they fit best. Two of the ribs have a thinner profile than the rest. They go in the front, to fit between the shoulders protruding form the front legs. I usually mount the rest of the ribs in descending size from the front. It doesn't look perfect, but I got tired of toying around with splines. Mount the bone neck shield to the head, then the neck, and finally the two sides of the head to avoid the neck conflicting with the two sides. I've thinned the neck to try to avoid this, but I'm not sure I took away enough material.
Enjoy your dino!
Dove

"He's electric green, he's midnight black, he's fights crime, with wings on his back! He's ModioMan!  ModioMan thrives on the energy of successful prints, and fights the crime of tangled filament and calibration errors! What will he do next, we will know next week on the ModioChallenge network!" - lmcleod1

Modio is an Apple IPad app that allows users of all ages to design their own unique 3D printable "thing"! This "thing" can be anything an imagination can create using the connectable joint pieces; planes, helicopters, superheros, animals, bugs, aliens, and more! There are unlimited possibilities! Once printed, the "thing" can be taken apart and reassembled a different way as well!
This is a nice shape to test the where the angles below 45 degrees need support material. It can be used as decoration, a ball for the cat or a Christmas Sphere (for next year).
Just hit Make and if you dont want overhang use the support material option.

Note: Units are in inches.
Method 1
Print "internals.stl" only and insert into a Wheatly Fly Box. These can cost anywhere from $20 to $80. The metal is much thinner than a 3d printer can do. At this point, I do not actually have a Wheatly Fly Box, so I do not know the exact measurements. It may require some modifications.
Method 2
Print "internals.stl," "inner ring.stl," and two copies of "housing.stl." The housing can be assembled using 1.75 mm filament as the hinge pin. Insert the internals, followed by the inner ring.

Table vice for a Shapeoko 2 that has a 1" grid drilled into it's bed. The mounting points for this clamp is 1" center to center and made for #6-32 screws. title: The J-Head Lite V2.1 Ultimate Economy RepRap 3D Printer Hot End

description.text:
As innovative as it is affordable, The J-Head Lite V2.1 is now more Bowden compatible. It has a removable upper portion of the liner, so that it can be used in either a direct drive or bowden configuration.
Specifically designed for 1.75mm filament, This design extrudes PLA and ABS, as well as many other plastics. The extruder can heat up to 250C. It sports the Honeywell 100K ohm thermistor for accurate temperature readings. Overall length is about 2.6" and weight is 1.2 ounces.
Setup:
You need to change the thermistor settings in your firmware:
define TEMP_SENSOR_0 1
to...
define TEMP_SENSOR_0 7
These PID settings are a good place to start:
define PID_INTEGRAL_DRIVE_MAX 15
define PID_PGAIN 2560
define PID_IGAIN 64
define PID_DGAIN 4096
Material:
PTFE wire sleeving (McMaster-Carr # 5335K13)
Brass nozzle (McMaster-Carr # 8952K33)
M6x1 stainless steal barrel (McMaster-Carr # 90024A461)
Brass nut (McMaster-Carr # 90690A047)
Vishay 6.8ohm resistor (Digikey # RWMA-6.8CT-ND)
Honeywell 100k thermistor (Digikey # 480-3135-ND)
Ceramic insulation (Cotronics # 390-42M)
Aluminum heater block (Clinton Aluminum .375"X.5" 6061)
Heat Resistant Wiring (Harbour Industrial # M22759/16-22-9)
Copper Heat Sink (Elkhart Products Corporation # 10030626)
FEP heat shrink tubing (Zoro Industrial Supplies # G2761595)
3mm PTFE tubing (Fluorotherm Polymers)
1/2" PTFE rod (Piedmont Plastics)
1/4" Oak mounting plate (Lowes)
For sale: http://www.ebay.com/itm/The-J-Head-Lite-V2-1-Ultimate-Economy-RepRap-3D-Printer-Hot-End-/261607085522?

Insert the 2mm rod into the PTFE tube (not all the way or it'll get stuck). This will ensure that the PTFE is threaded properly. Thread the first nut onto the tube. Add the second nut to back up the first. Remove the metal rod.

comments.text: I needed it to print nylon, but it also improved PLA printing speeds and decreased clogging.  Whether it's helpful on your RigidBot will depend on your spring tension, trim pot settings, and several other factors.  If your extruder fails by slipping (it doesn't extrude the length of filament you specified, but the motor doesn't miss any steps), you're probably not using all the torque available and this might help.  If it fails with the extruder missing steps, this may make things worse.  If you're not sure, try extruding 100mm of filament at various speeds and check at what speed does the extrusion start to fail with and without the washer.

Plastocyanin, also called blue copper protein, is a copper-containing protein involved in electron-transfer:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plastocyanin The model is of the Cu II form of plastocyanin, with four ligands to the copper (II) ion. These are N(His37) S(Cys84) N(His87) and S(Met92). Model of Plastocyanin from Poplar based on the Protein Data Bank entry 1PLC:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=1plc STL file created using VMD:
http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/ The protein backbone is represented in "cartoon" form. The copper-binding histidines, cysteine and methionine, and copper ion are shown.

Successfully printed by a Replicator 2 in PLA using MakerWare(TM) 2.4.1.24, standard resolution (3 shells, 25% infill), with raft and supports. Different representations are provided as a guide to coloring the molecule by hand.
IF you are studying material science this thing helps you visualize atomic structures in metals and ceramics. It looks cool anyways just to have it. VIDEO https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=09GCkKRWOoA

To print this you will need a printer with dual extruders. The next step is to open Makerware. upload first, than second, scale it to 50 mm(both of them). Center both objects and voila. I printed PLA with original settings. takes ~3-4 hours.

title: Makerfarm Prusa i3v Spool Holder Extension

description.text:
I got some spools of filament in that were a little to big for the stock spool holder that comes with the Makerfarm 8" Prusa i3v, so I made a little extender for it to accomodate this. --Update--
I have uploaded a Version 2 of the base that contains a cutout for the screw that can get in the way. --Update 2--
I have uploaded a "short" version of the base which will not come so close to the Z-Axis rod, as well as a Version 2 that includes a tool holder. Additionally, I have uploaded a top piece with a cut for those rolls that have the filament coming through the center.

Printed on a Makerfarm 8" Prusa i3v in ABS at 0.20mm layer height and 20% infill.  
Use the stock vertical members and the same hardware as the stock spool holder.

I am currently only using the rear two pieces to locate the glass.  Instead of binder clips I use silicone pads to hold the glass.  Ifound that binder clips would transfer the warp of the build plate, silicone pads allows the glass to float above and remain flat
Printed at .2 layer height.  should be used in same order printed.  The binder clip on the back right corner should be on the back edge of the glass to avoid the print head.

author: billsprototypestudio

description.text:
This is one of those projects that started off as a modeling exercise and turned into something usable. This mug holds about 3.25 cups of liquid, although 24oz is probably as close as you can get if you figure in ice, etc. When printed at 100% infill, it is absolutely water-tight.
It's big enough to act as a shaving soap mug, if you use Proraso shaving soap. I'm sure it would work fine as a water cup as well, assuming that you use a pigment-free PLA to print it with,you don't put anything hot in it, you don't put it in a dishwasher, and you don't mind a few atoms of lead hitchhiking on the plastic from your hotend.

If you intend to make this watertight, print it at 100% infill with 5 extra shells and full supports. On my Replicator 1, it took about 14 hours to print and used up roughly 8.5 ounces of filament. I had to do some cleanup with 320 grit sandpaper to get rid of burs from the supports.
If you don't need it to be water tight, you can get away with 25% infill and 1 additional shell.
If you need to reduce the size of the mug, keep in mind that the wall and bottom thickness is 5mm.

A front or rear facing mount for Adafruit's 1W White LED and a x4 AA battery pack mount as a power source (only use 3 AA for the 1W LED).
https://www.adafruit.com/product/518 DANGER! Drivers may become entranced by your lights and start to veer towards you. This is completely normal, they are merely entranced by your awesomeness and suffering from target fixation.

1) Print one of each part
2) Mount onto existing screws (Does not work with truck risers)
3) Attach 1W LED using a M3 screw in the smaller hole
4) Solder power wires through the larger hole
5) Use provided holes to ziptie power wires
6) Heat bend the battery clamp tab downwards so it snap fits the pack
7) Tape a few layers of fabric to the side of the battery pack that is in contact with the board, this will reduce vibration noise
8) For a rear facing light, tape clear red tape over the LED.

There are many sculpting type programs to explore

title: Pickling press for 24oz wide mouth mason jars

description.text: Replace the band and lid of a standard 24oz jar with this and keep your pickles/sauerkraut/tsukemono/kimchi/whatever under compression and submerged. Check out this page for some handy info: http://www.theblackmoon.com/Jfood/ftsuke.html Requires both the jar and a spring (available online or at some hardware stores) - everything else is printable. Plate can be adjusted downward for more/less food, compression, etc. Max this will take at once is about 15oz/60% full with post screwed all the way in and plate fully compressed. Post can fall out extended all the way out, and plate/knob should be snug enough to stay put but allow disassembly for easy cleaning. Inspired by existing Japanese pickle presses you can buy at stores... but are pretty expensive. Samples printed in PLA. The usual disclaimer - use/eat at your own risk. If you've never made pickled anything, then it might be good to practice a bit. Not sure of any long term effects of food contact with PLA, but improperly pickled rotten food can surely wreck you. Don't put the plastic parts in the dishwasher. Hand wash. May try to print one with fda-cool PET some time... when I get my damn printers to not choke on the stuff. And always use pure/Kosher salt. Iodized salt or other salt with additives can make your pickles ugly and discolored.

First get some Ball mason jars - 24oz/1.5 pint variety.
like these:http://www.walmart.com/ip/21290196
Then 3/4" OD by 3-3/8" long .047 wire gauge compression spring: http://monsterfastener.com/item/sprc-373?gclid=CNbT5dLlgMECFYdlfgodf0EAeA
Print all parts (I used 0.25mm layers/30% fill/3 perimeters on all but the "plunger" which i made denser - 50% fill).
Spring goes into "lowerpost2" compressed by "plunger" and secured with "lowerpostcap2". "Plate" slips snugly onto plunger end. All that screws into the "upperpost2" which goes through "lid" and is secured with "knob". You will likely need to do a bit of surface sanding on the posts and plunger to make the plunger move easily and the screw action work well.

comments.text: Nice work, this really shows off what is possible with 3D printing: interfacing with real-world objects, close-fitting parts, working threads (both internal and external). I printed in ABS and it turned out perfectly. I may go back and coat the plunger piece with something to make it officially food-safe, but for now I'm just happy to look at it and let people see that cool working parts can be made.

comments.text: Nicely done -- and thanks for sharing! I assume these do not prevent oxygen from reaching the jar contents like the various air lock lid designs. Has this been a problem for you at all (mold, etc.)? What's your basic process?
comments.author: CLine

comments.text: CLine, you're thinking of fermenting, which is a different process than simple pickling. Produce soaked in vinegar doesn't have the same mold issues that a saltwater brine would offer.
comments.author: CLine

comments.text: These don't actually have an airlock design in them.  The screw hole in top should be slightly loose, so it is enough to let gasses escape and minimize convection of other air (and baddies) into the jar. Pretty much the same theory as the ones I've bought in the local Japanese grocer. It's not ideal, especially for anything that needs to ferment in warmer places for longer times, I suppose.  For a short pickle that can be done in the fridge, it's been great.  I've had great luck with things like Japanese shiozuke (salt cured), kimchee, etc. My luck with sauerkraut has not been so good... no mold... just nothing.
comments.author: CLine

So the gears print out hollow, then when it goes to cover them, it cant, cuz its way too far to bridge.
I had support on, but only for where it touches the build plate, maybe if you had it turned on for internal parts it would work.
If the design was redone so the STL file only had the External surfaces, and not the inset part of the gears, it would work.
Look at the layers in Cura and you will see what I mean.

remixed_from.author: dc42
remixed_from.title: Enclosure for Duet + optional DueX4 electronics

title: Rear-mounted Duet enclosure for RepRapPro Ormerod 1

description.text:
This is an enclusore for the Duet controller board, to be mounted on the rear of the printer atop the power PCB (which also goes into the same enclosure). This is similar to where it is mounted on the Ormerod 2. Parametric design where most dimensions on the enclosure are easily customisable.
Based on existing work by bobtidey and dc42, see sources for links.

Many features of the enclosure can be turned on or off by boolean variables in the top section. Enc_basic_inner_height can be adjusted depending on the height of your connectors, and can also be a lot lower if you don't have the acrylic lid on. enclosure_spacing controls how high the Duet is, depending on how high your bed is mounted. If it is too low, the lower mounting screws might hit the bed.
There is also an extra hole in the top for a reset button, since the one on the board is quite hard to get to. This can be wired to the reset and ground pins of the expansion header (pins 2 and 4, the two pins at the end of the row closest to the edge of the board). To connect the power PCB to the Duet, I used 2.5mm2 solid-core electric installation cable, which is easily bent into the proper shape and works well with the screw terminals.
Some of the cables will also be too short after this. I used the loom for the Y motor and connected to the Z motor, and cut the old Z loom apart and extended it to use for Y. Similarly also had to extend the endstop cables.
The enclosure is mounted with the same screws, nuts and plywood washers as the original enclosures. The difference is the upper mount where I replaced the screw with a shorter one and no washers. The original one works but you will need one or maybe even two washers.
Before printing, verify that the Z carriage can move freely and that the Z runner does not hit the enclosure. Some additional info can be found in the reprap forums

title: Flexyhand test for filaflex tendons reversed system

description.text:
This is quick test for a new system where the standard system of opening the wrist is reversed, in a way that the elastics keep the hand closed with the finger clenched and moving the wrist downwards makes the hand open.
In this test I enlarged the channels in the fingers palm side to allow for a thicker cord such as filaflex or other strong elastic to contract the fingers. At the base of the finger I made a hole to tie the elastic.
On the back of the finger and connecting into the channels in the palm there is a new channel for non-elastic cord that will open the hand when the wrist is moved downwards.
Only the finger index has been done, once its proven to work well it will be further developed.
With this system, the stronger the elastic and the more tension it has, the better the grip strength will be. Consequently the effort to open the hand by pushing the wrist downwards will require less or more effort depending on the tension of the elastic. With this balance of forces the user can choose how strong the grip is according to his wrist strength. A system to regulate the tension of the elastic could also be developed, perhaps using boa fasteners or similar. Another advantage of this system is that it has adaptive grip, this means that when grabbing a ball the fingers will automatically adapt to the shape of the ball thus increasing the grabbing capability.
Another advantage will be that the user wont have to keep the wrist muscle in tension while holding an item, only when the hand needs to be opened so it will be an advantage for things like riding a bike or rowing or something like that
Here is a video demostration by Steve Wood on how it would work with a Talon hand using Filaflex as an elastic.
Talon Hand - Normally Closed
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gPE68kLHkwY&feature=youtu.be
Any feedback from people willing to test it would be great. It works best with filaflex filament as an elastic but you can also use any strong elastic, the stronger the better as long as its thickness fit through the channels at the front of the fingers?
This is a remix from +Steve Wood design. Is very much a work in progress

You need to print the 3 parts of the finger as well as the palm part in ABS or PLA.
The joints are made of flexible filament, best is filaflex though other brands work too.
There is only one finger to test, the index finger. Once you put the pieces together, you can string it.
First you can run an elastic cord at the forefront of the fingers, such as flexible filament like filaflex or other strong elastic. There are holes to tie it to the tip of the finger and at the top of the palm where the finger base rests.
Then you run a strong Non-flexible cord through the back of the fingers and down the channels in the palm out into the wrist.
I didnt include the gauntlet since just pulling the string would be enough for the test.
You will need the filaflex joints printed and scaled appropriately to fit.
Amongst aforementioned changes, this hand as been scaled down from the original to 76% which you can find here with all the original files, including the filaflex joints which should be scaled accordingly.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380665

title: Mendel Max Printrboard holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pretty self explanatory really, mounts the Printrboard 3D printer controller in the back right corner of your printer with the comms cable oriented to go straight out the back and with the SD card port and rest button on the top where you can get to them easily. Also features plenty of cable tie holes all around the board to help tidy up your wiring (I'll post another photo of mine wired up when I get on to that).
Lines up with the two side rails and mounts using standard T-nuts and M5 machine screws.

Print it out and clear out all the holes.
Printrboard mounting holes are 3mm, use M3 macing screws and have captive nuts.
Cable tie holes are all 4mm.
The four mounting holes are 5mm.

I'm a happy KitchenAid user. We'll have guests for dinner. I have a meat grinder but I do not have the sausage stuffer accessory yet. The local KitchenAid dealer has out of stock. I want to make some sausage filled tenderloins for dinner. Oh wait, I have a 3D printer!-) These parts just plain tubes - I hope I won't violate any patent by publishing these designs. https://www.youmagine.com/designs/kitchenaid-sausage-stuffer

Printed with Cura 12.12: layer height = 0.1mm, infill = 100%, "Joris the outer edge" was turned on in expert settings (I'm not sure it was necessary since the tube wall thickness is more than 1mm).
Print tooks ~100 mins / tube. If you have to fill proper sausage I recommend the big tube.

title: Four speed gearbox with H shifter

description.text:
The gears have the following teeth / ratios
1st 40 18 2.22
2nd 38 22 1.72
3rd 36 26 1.38
4th 32 32 1.00

The gears, hubs etc sit on 8mm threaded rod and
are held in place by jam nuts either end.
The threaded rod passes through some stands but
really some bearings are needed in the future.
http://youtu.be/zyc-CCEKLo8

description.header: Print the following for the gear cassette
description.text:
assem_gear*.stl (8 gears, 4 have lugs to fit baulk rings)
assem_baulk_holed.stl (x4)
assem_hub.stl (x4)
assem_spacer.stl (x2)
assem_stator.stl (x2)
assem_selring_grooved.stl (x2)
assem_fork_holed (x2)
assem_stand.stl (x4)

description.header: Print the following for the H shifter
description.text:
assem_hlower.stl (x1)
assem_hplate.stl (x1)
assem_pivotbar_grooved.stl (x1)
assem_slider_pair.stl (x1)
assem_gearknob.stl (x1)

You'll need about a meter or more of threaded rod.
About 40-50 nuts. About 15 washers.

Each shaft has one selector ring set. The selector ring sits over the stator (which is locked to the shaft) when in neutral. The gears are spinning freely on hubs. The selector ring shifts either way to lock a baulk ring (or "dog") to the stator. Since the baulk ring is linked to a gear via the lugs, a gear is now locked to the stator, and is engaged.
On a 8mm theaded rod shaft, add a stator. Add a baulk ring either side of the stator, with triangle teeth pointing toward the stator. Slip a selector ring over the stator.

Place a hub with the flanged end on a table and slip a gear (gear1a) over the hub with lugs pointing up. Add the hub and gear to the shaft and mate the lugs into the baulk ring. Do the same on the other side using gear2a. You should now be able to squeeze the two hubs toward each other with your fingers and notice that the stator is locked and the gears spin.
The opposite shaft should match with the following: gear1b, spacer,  gear2b.
Repeat the whole assembly process, but this time on the opposite shaft for gears 3 and 4.
For each shaft add a washer and jam nut each end, and tighten. The stators and spacers (with gears) will be locked, and the 4 gears on hubs will spin freely.
Put the shafts through stands and use more threaded rod crossways to ensure the shafts are 51mm apart. Note: better stands with bearings are needed.
See photos for now.

description.header: Known constants of the gear cassette
description.text:
The shafts' centers are 51mm apart.
The travel from neutral to select any gear is 6mm.

Too much threaded rod. But it is adjustable.
A bit clunky. Forks could be smaller for more precision.
The H box sits on rotating shafts. Needs own stand really.

title: Customizable starry, curvy, bowl, cup or vase
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Design your own bowl, cup, vase, candle holder, Christmas ball, bracelet, ring, ashtray, hourglass or other thing with this customizable design. I think it is pretty versatile so I am very curious what other uses you come up with.
Open this in customizer, play with the sliders, fiddle with the sizes and make something beautiful!!

New Features:
I have added the possibility to make the middle thinner than the bottom and top. Use a negative value for the curve to get a thinner middle. I have added a cylindrical hole so you can make candle holders, rings, etcetera

Tips:
Openscad has some limitations that cause some failures in the stl files for some of these models. You can use the netfabb default repair to fix your stl. You can find a manual here: http://3daddfab.com/blog/index.php?/archives/10-Automatically-Repair-STL-Files-in-2-Minutes-with-netfabb.html There are sliders for the wall and bottom thickness for vases, bowls etc. but if you can control the print settings you get nicer results with a solid stl model.
Customizer settings:
-Bottom thickness: Bigger than your height
Slicer settings:
-infill settings: 0
-top layers : 0
-number of perimeters: 2 or more
-bottom thickness: 3 or more bottom layers. If you do not use support you should be careful not to get to much overhang. Overhang happens faster with:
  • a bottom diameter that is much smaller than the top diameter,
  • big curves
  • big grooves

title: New Dark Repulser Sword Multi Print Ready

description.text:
This is a updated sword based upon thing:399131. I've sliced up the
sword into 6 different parts to make it easy to print. I've also added
connection holes for pins on each part. These holes are used for align-ment and I've include a "Pins .stl" you can use. You could also
use the alignment holes to drill larger holes for dowels. I've also
included a .STL that has all the pieces on a single build platform. This way you can print out all the pieces in one print.

My 3d printers build platform is 150 x 200 x 200. So all parts max
height (z) is 175. If your printer Z is less than 175 then you will need
to scale ALL parts(6 stl's) the same percentage.
Print all 6 parts or choose to print the sword all at once with the
"Complete" stl.

comments.text: I'm thinking of re-doing the sword to give it more strength.  My kids wanted this sword to hang on their bedroom wall.  Would of been fine if that was the case.  Well I caught them swinging it and I had printed with 20% infill (honeycomb) and the handle snapped easily from one swing.  So I think I'm going to modify it this weekend to have a single DOWEL hole from the Handle --> thru the Hilt---> thru the sections of the blade --> to the tip.   I have a long wood dowel 3 feet that I'm going to run up it.  I'll glue the dowel to the handle and then slide each piece on and glue it as well.  So it should help with the alignment as well as give it strength enough to be swung.  I will also not need to print the sword "Solid" infill so it will keep it light.

title: Art Deco Pipe:  The ABS Express

description.text:
Fans of Art Deco will love the arrayed teardrop theme of this Art Deco Pipe, appropriately named "The ABS Express" to convey imagery of speed on the road, in the air, or thru the water... or even outer space. Nothing says "fast" like a teardrop, yet the divided array of teardrops and the angle from which we view them are more architectural and neon-signage as typically seen in Art Deco Architecture.
So is it a building going fast, a rocket sled on wheels, or... or... could it be a cannabis pipe? I will test it for proper operation!
Les

The ABS should resist most of the heat of normal smoking, however to minimize fumes and for best operation, fold a piece of aluminum foil few times while constantly reshaping it into the ellipsoid shape of the bowl.
Remember to fill the bowl and empty it frequently for proper operation of your neurons and other hardware devices.
Les
